Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: High denitrification potential but low nitrous oxide emission in a constructed wetland treating nitrate-polluted agricultural run-off.

AbstractText: Constructed wetlands (CW) can efficiently remove nitrogen from polluted agricultural run-off, however, a potential caveat is nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), a harmful greenhouse gas and stratospheric ozone depleter. During five sampling campaigns, we measured N<sub>2</sub>O fluxes from a 0.53 ha off-stream CW treating nitrate-rich water from the intensively fertilized watershed in Rampillon, France, using automated chambers with a quantum cascade laser system, and manual chambers. Sediment samples were analysed for potential N<sub>2</sub> flux using the HeO<sub>2</sub> incubation method. Both inlet nitrate (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>) concentrations and N<sub>2</sub>O emission varied significantly between the seasons. In the Autumn and Winter inlet concentrations were about 11 mg NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>-N L<sup>-1</sup>, and < 6.5 mg NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>-N L<sup>-1</sup> in the Spring and Summer. N<sub>2</sub>O emission was highest in the Autumn (mean ± standard error: 9.7 ± 0.2 μg N m<sup>-2</sup> h<sup>-1</sup>) and lowest in the Summer (wet period: 0.2 ± 0.3 μg N m<sup>-2</sup> h<sup>-1</sup>). The CW was a very weak source of N<sub>2</sub>O emitting 0.32 kg N<sub>2</sub>O-N ha<sup>-1</sup> yr<sup>-1</sup> and removing around 938 kg NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>-N ha<sup>-1</sup> yr<sup>-1</sup>, the ratio of N<sub>2</sub>O-N emitted to NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>-N removed was 0.033%. The automated and manual chambers gave similar results. From the potential N<sub>2</sub>O formation in the sediment, only 9% was emitted to the atmosphere, the average N<sub>2</sub> N <sub>2</sub>O ratio was high: 89:1 for N<sub>2</sub>-N<sub>potential</sub>: N<sub>2</sub>O-N<sub>potential</sub> and 1353:1 for N<sub>2</sub>-N<sub>potential</sub>: N<sub>2</sub>O-N<sub>emitted</sub>. These results indicate complete denitrification. The focused principal component analysis showed strong positive correlation between the gaseous N<sub>2</sub>O fluxes and the following environmental factors: NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>-N concentrations in inlet water, streamflow, and nitrate reduction rate. Water temperature, TOC and DOC in the water and hydraulic residence time showed negative correlations with N<sub>2</sub>O emissions. Shallow off-stream CWs such as Rampillon may have good nitrate removal capacity with low N<sub>2</sub>O emissions.
